distribution.text: Copyright 2024 SUSE LLC. All rights reserved.

notes.text:
This update for rsync fixes the following issues:

- Update to version 3.2.3 (jsc#SLE-21252, jsc#PED-3146)
- Add support for using --atimes to preserve atime of files in destination sync (jsc#PED-3145)
- Remove SuSEfirewall2 service as this was replaced by firewalld (which already provides a rsyncd service).
- Fix --delay-updates never updates after interruption (bsc#1204538)
- Arbitrary file write vulnerability via do_server_recv function (bsc#1201840, CVE-2022-29154)
- rsync-ssl: Verify the hostname in the certificate when using openssl. (bsc#1176160, CVE-2020-14387)
notes.title: Description of the patch

notes.text: A flaw was found in rsync in versions since 3.2.0pre1. Rsync improperly validates certificate with host mismatch vulnerability. A remote, unauthenticated attacker could exploit the flaw by performing a man-in-the-middle attack using a valid certificate for another hostname which could compromise confidentiality and integrity of data transmitted using rsync-ssl. The highest threat from this vulnerability is to data confidentiality and integrity. This flaw affects rsync versions before 3.2.4.
notes.title: CVE description

notes.text: An issue was discovered in rsync before 3.2.5 that allows malicious remote servers to write arbitrary files inside the directories of connecting peers. The server chooses which files/directories are sent to the client. However, the rsync client performs insufficient validation of file names. A malicious rsync server (or Man-in-The-Middle attacker) can overwrite arbitrary files in the rsync client target directory and subdirectories (for example, overwrite the .ssh/authorized_keys file).
notes.title: CVE description
